questions.text: A patient present with a history of repeated thoughts that their hands are unclean and repetitive handwashing. The treating psychiatrist makes a diagnosis of OCD. Which of the following statements about obsessions are true? Obsessions are disorders of possession of thought. Obsessions are ego-syntonic. Patients try to resist obsessions. Obsessions can be in the form of images.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • 2. Obsessions are ego-syntonic: False . Obsessions are ego-dystonic , meaning they are not agreeable to self. This causes the individual to experience distress and attempt to resist or suppress these thoughts.
  • • 2. Obsessions are ego-syntonic:
  • • False
  • • Obsessions are ego-dystonic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessions are intrusive, distressing thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced as uncontrollable (disorders of thought possession). They are typically ego-dystonic , meaning they are not aligned with the individual's self-concept, and patients often try to resist them.
  • ➤ Obsessions are intrusive, distressing thoughts, urges, or images
  • ➤ experienced as uncontrollable
  • ➤ typically ego-dystonic
  • ➤ they are not aligned
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient presents to a psychiatrist with a complaint that whenever he passes by a dog, he feels that he has been scratched by the dog and will contract rabies. He often checks his body parts for signs of a bite. Over time, the symptoms have escalated, and even if he sees a dog at a distance, he starts looking for bite marks and has visited the emergency department on several occasions to receive the vaccination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Zoophobia: This diagnosis refers to an excessive or irrational fear of animals , specifically dogs , in this case. However, the patient's primary concern is related to the fear of contracting rabies after being scratched or bitten by the dog, rather than the fear of the dog itself. While the fear of dogs may be a component of the patient's anxiety, the repetitive checking behaviour and intrusive thoughts are more characteristic of OCD, making this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option A. Zoophobia:
  • • diagnosis refers to an excessive or irrational fear of animals
  • • dogs
  • • Option B. Illness Anxiety Disorder: Patients with Illness Anxiety Disorder have a preoccupation with having or developing a serious illness , despite a lack of physical symptoms or only mild symptoms . Although the patient is anxious about getting rabies, the primary issue is the repetitive checking behaviour and the intrusive thoughts about contracting rabies, which are hallmark symptoms of OCD. The focus on checking for bite marks and seeking vaccinations, rather than a generalized anxiety about having an illness, makes OCD a more accurate diagnosis.
  • • Option B. Illness Anxiety Disorder:
  • • Patients with Illness Anxiety Disorder have a preoccupation with having or developing a serious illness
  • • lack of physical symptoms or only mild symptoms
  • • Option D. Somatic Symptom Disorder: In Somatic Symptom Disorder , patients experience physical symptoms that cause significant distress and impairment , and they may have excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to those symptoms . While the patient is concerned about physical symptoms (bite marks), the primary issue is the repetitive checking behavior and intrusive thoughts about rabies. These symptoms are more consistent with OCD, making it the more appropriate diagnosis for this patient.
  • • Option D. Somatic Symptom Disorder:
  • • Somatic Symptom Disorder
  • • experience physical symptoms that cause significant distress and impairment
  • • they may have excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to those symptoms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is characterized by presence of obsessions (recurrent and intrusive thoughts, images or impulses which cause marked anxiety or distress) and compulsive acts (repetitive behaviors such as handwashing, checking or mental acts such as counting, praying that person performs in response to an obsession).
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • ➤ characterized by presence of obsessions
  • ➤ compulsive acts
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presents to the psychiatry outpatient department, stating, "Doctor, I feel like a horrible person and am ashamed of myself. I keep having inappropriate thoughts about God, and despite my attempts to avoid these thoughts, I can't control them. I don't understand why I think this way. I spend hours each day apologizing to God, fearing divine punishment." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder: This diagnosis involves excessive anxiety and worry about various aspects of life , occurring for at least six months . Although the patient is experiencing anxiety, the primary concern revolves around intrusive thoughts about God and the compulsive behavior of apologizing. These symptoms are more consistent with OCD.
  • • Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder:
  • • involves excessive anxiety and worry about various aspects of life
  • • occurring for at least six months
  • • Option B. Impulse Control Disorder: Impulse control disorders involve a failure to resist an urge to engage in a harmful behavior . The patient's symptoms do not match this diagnosis, as the primary issue is the presence of intrusive thoughts and compulsive actions, which are characteristic of OCD.
  • • Option B. Impulse Control Disorder:
  • • involve a failure to resist an urge to engage in a harmful behavior
  • • Option D. Major Depressive Disorder: Although the patient expresses negative feelings about themselves , the primary concern is the intrusive thoughts and compulsive behavior . The symptoms described are more indicative of OCD than Major Depressive Disorder.
  • • Option D. Major Depressive Disorder:
  • • patient expresses negative feelings about themselves
  • • primary concern is the intrusive thoughts
  • • compulsive behavior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's presentation of uncontrollable , inappropriate thoughts about God and the compulsive behavior of apologizing for hours each day to avoid feared divine punishment is consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). OCD is characterized by obsessions (intrusive, distressing thoughts or images) and compulsions (repetitive behaviors aimed at neutralizing the distress caused by the obsessions).
  • ➤ patient's presentation of uncontrollable
  • ➤ inappropriate thoughts about God
  • ➤ compulsive behavior of apologizing for hours each day
  • ➤ feared divine punishment is consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient is being treated for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). With respect to the management of OCD, which of the following statements are correct? Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice. Antipsychotics are often used as an augmentation agent in the treatment.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Statement 4 is correct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD: This statement is not entirely correct . Both clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) and SSRIs are considered first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD. However, due to the more favorable side effect profile of SSRIs, they are often preferred as the initial pharmacological treatment choice. Clomipramine is highly effective but generally reserved for cases where SSRIs are not effective or tolerated due to its side effects.
  • • 1. Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD:
  • • not entirely correct
  • • 2. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD: This statement is incorrect . Mood stabilizers are not typically considered first-line treatment options for OCD. The first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD are SSRIs and clomipramine.
  • • 2. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD:
  • • incorrect
  • • 3. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice: This statement is incorrect . While systematic desensitization (a type of exposure therapy) can be used in the treatment of specific phobias, the therapy of choice for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a type of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT). ERP involves exposing the patient to situations that trigger obsessions and preventing the compulsive response, which is different from systematic desensitization.
  • • 3. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice:
  • • incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD are SSRIs and clomipramine , with SSRIs often preferred due to their side effect profile . Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a form of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT), is the therapy of choice for OCD . Antipsychotics can be used as augmentation agents in treatment-resistant cases or when there is a partial response to first-line treatments. Mood stabilizers are not typically considered first-line treatments for OCD.
  • ➤ first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD are SSRIs and clomipramine
  • ➤ SSRIs often preferred due to their side effect profile
  • ➤ Exposure and Response Prevention
  • ➤ Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
  • ➤ therapy of choice for OCD
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 424.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 424.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the psychiatrist by her mother. The mother complains that her daughter continuously collects various useless items and never discards anything. The mother is frustrated because the entire house is cluttered as a result. The patient expresses a desire to throw away the useless items but fears losing something she may need later. The patient's condition belongs to which diagnostic category?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Impulse control disorder involves difficulty in resisting the urge to perform an act that could be harmful to oneself or others , such as pyromania (setting fires) or kleptomania (stealing). The patient's behavior does not indicate an impulse to perform potentially harmful acts, but rather a difficulty in discarding possessions due to fear of needing them later.
  • • Option A. Impulse control disorder
  • • difficulty in resisting the urge to perform an act that could be harmful to oneself or others
  • • pyromania
  • • kleptomania
  • • Option C. Personality disorders are characterized by enduring patterns of inner experience and behavior that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture , are pervasive and inflexible , and lead to distress or impairment . While hoarding can be a feature of certain personality disorders (such as obsessive-compulsive personality disorder), the specific description of distress related to the inability to discard items and fear of losing something needed later is more indicative of Hoarding Disorder.
  • • Option C. Personality disorders
  • • characterized by enduring patterns of inner experience and behavior
  • • deviate markedly from the expectations
  • • individual's culture
  • • pervasive and inflexible
  • • lead to distress or impairment
  • • Option D. Anxiety and fear-related disorders include conditions where anxiety or fear is the predominant feature , such as generalized anxiety disorder , panic disorder , and phobias . While anxiety can be a component of Hoarding Disorder, particularly anxiety about discarding items, the specific symptoms described are more characteristic of an obsessive-compulsive and related disorder.
  • • Option D. Anxiety and fear-related disorders
  • • conditions where anxiety or fear is the predominant feature
  • • generalized anxiety disorder
  • • panic disorder
  • • phobias

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders in DSM-5 :
  • ➤ Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders in DSM-5
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 419.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the psychiatrist with concerns about her appearance. She reports that she believes her nose is severely deformed and that everyone around her is constantly staring at it. Her family and friends have reassured her multiple times that her nose appears normal, but she remains convinced that it is a significant defect. She spends hours each day looking in the mirror, comparing her nose to pictures of others, and researching surgical options. She has even stopped attending social events due to her fear of being judged. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Body dysmorphic disorder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Body-focused repetitive behavior disorder: This disorder is characterized by recurrent behaviors focused on one's body , such as hair-pulling (trichotillomania), or skin-picking (excoriation). The patient's symptoms do not align with this disorder, as her primary concern is a perceived defect in her appearance rather than engaging in repetitive behaviors.
  • • Option B. Body-focused repetitive behavior disorder:
  • • characterized by recurrent behaviors focused on one's body
  • • hair-pulling
  • • skin-picking
  • • Option C. Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month , without other psychotic symptoms . This patient presents with a preoccupations followed by repetitive behaviours in relation to that preoccupation, this goes more in favour of body dysmorphic disorder. In case the patient develops a firm, fixed belief, even then, the diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional belief will be favoured over the diagnosis of delusional disorder
  • • Option C. Delusional disorder:
  • • presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month
  • • without other psychotic symptoms
  • • Option D. Social anxiety disorder: Social anxiety disorder is characterized by a persistent fear of social situations due to concerns about being judged or humiliated. While the patient does avoid social events, her avoidance is primarily driven by her perceived appearance defect, making body dysmorphic disorder the more accurate diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Social anxiety disorder:
  • • characterized by a persistent fear of social situations due to concerns about being judged or humiliated.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is characterized by the preoccupation with an imagined defect in body appearance. In case, a slight physical anomaly is present , the patient's concern for the same is exaggerated. The location of the imagined defect is usually hair, nose and skin.
  • ➤ Body Dysmorphic Disorder
  • ➤ preoccupation
  • ➤ imagined defect
  • ➤ body appearance.
  • ➤ slight physical anomaly is present
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 416.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 416.

Ans. B) Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders

  • • difficulties resisting the urge to engage in behaviors
  • • harmful to oneself or others
  • • Option C. Personality disorders: Personality disorders involve enduring patterns of inner experiences and behaviors that deviate significantly from cultural expectations and lead to distress or impairment in various areas of life . The patient's hair-pulling behavior is not indicative of a personality disorder.
  • • Option C. Personality disorders:
  • • enduring patterns of inner experiences and behaviors that deviate
  • • cultural expectations and lead to distress or impairment in various areas of life
  • • Option D. Anxiety and fear-related disorders: Although anxiety may be present in individuals with trichotillomania, the primary feature of the patient's condition is hair-pulling, which falls under the category of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders.

  • • anxiety may be present in individuals with trichotillomania,

questions.text: You discussed with your consultant a 27-year-old male patient who attended the OPD with his sister. He reports persistent and distressing visions of himself involved in severe accidents. These visions are so troubling that he meticulously reassesses safety measures, trying to prevent such perceived events. His fears have become so overwhelming that he frequently avoids travel and sometimes even refuses to leave his home. Despite acknowledging the irrationality of these thoughts, he feels powerless to dispel them. Your consultant inquires about the neural pathways possibly associated with his symptoms. Which of the following brain circuits is most likely implicated in his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Frontostriatal pathway

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mesolimbic pathway: This is associated with reward, pleasure, and, when dysregulated , is involved in the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions).
  • • Option A. Mesolimbic pathway:
  • • associated with reward, pleasure, and, when dysregulated
  • • positive symptoms of schizophrenia
  • • Option C. Tuberoinfundibular pathway: This is involved in the regulation of prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland . Dysregulation (e.g., due to antipsychotic medications) can lead to hyperprolactinemia.
  • • Option C. Tuberoinfundibular pathway:
  • • involved in the regulation of prolactin secretion
  • • anterior pituitary gland
  • • Option D. Nigrostriatal pathway: This is associated with movement and motor control. Degeneration of this pathway is implicated in Parkinson's disease, and side effects from some antipsychotic drugs can impact this pathway, resulting in extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • • Option D. Nigrostriatal pathway:
  • • associated with movement and motor control.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysfunction in the cortico-striato-thalamico-cortical tract i.e., fronto-striatal tract (​​a neural circuit that starts in the orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex, and projects to the striatum, from the striatum to the thalamus and back to the cortex) has been hypothesized to be responsible for the development of OCD .
  • ➤ Dysfunction

  • ➤ fronto-striatal tract

questions.text: A 29-year-old software engineer named Aditya presented with distressing, repetitive thoughts about contamination. Despite washing his hands until they were raw, he couldn't shake off the belief that they were dirty. Aditya's work performance was deteriorating, and he had begun to isolate himself from his colleagues and friends. An MRI of his brain was ordered to rule out any structural anomalies. In the context of the above clinical picture, which specific brain structure, when showing abnormal activity or morphological changes, might be contributing to Aditya's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Caudate nucleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Amygdala: It is associated with emotion processing and fear responses . While it has a role in anxiety disorders, it's not specifically tied to the core pathology of OCD.
  • • Option A. Amygdala:
  • • associated with emotion processing and fear responses
  • • Option C. Hippocampus: This structure is primarily involved in memory consolidation . It has been discussed in the context of disorders like Alzheimer's disease and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
  • • Option C. Hippocampus:
  • • primarily involved in memory consolidation
  • • Option D. Putamen: Although a part of the striatum (like the caudate nucleus), it is more associated with motor functions and is notably involved in conditions like Parkinson's disease .
  • • Option D. Putamen:
  • • part of the striatum
  • • more associated with motor functions
  • • Parkinson's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Studies have found a bilaterally small caudate nucleus in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder .
  • ➤ bilaterally small caudate nucleus
  • ➤ obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 426.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 426.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman seeks help, distressed by persistent intrusive thoughts about engaging in inappropriate sexual acts with strangers. These thoughts go against her personal values and cause her significant anxiety. She constantly seeks reassurance that she won't act on these thoughts. What condition is she most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

  • • Explanation:

  • • characterized by episodes of mania or hypomania and depression
  • • Option C. Borderline Personality Disorder: This disorder involves a pattern of unstable relationships, self-image, and affect, along with impulsivity . While it can include anxiety and intrusive thoughts, the nature and content of the thoughts described are more consistent with OCD.

  • • disorder involves a pattern of unstable relationships, self-image, and affect, along with impulsivity
  • • Option D. Nymphomania: Now more commonly referred to as compulsive sexual behaviour disorder , this condition involves excessive or uncontrollable sexual urges or behaviors . However, the patient’s distress and fear about these thoughts, and the fact that they are unwanted and intrusive, align more with OCD than with hypersexuality.
  • • Option D. Nymphomania:
  • • compulsive sexual behaviour disorder
  • • involves excessive or uncontrollable sexual urges or behaviors
